did.abstract: Gilbert Ketcham joined the U. S. Army in 1942 and served overseas in North Africa and Italy until 1944. He was then stationed at Camp McQuade in California, where he monitored prisoners. The collection contains approximately 900 pages of correspondence and other material sent between Ketcham and his wife, Jean Seeley Ketcham, during the war.

bioghist.p: Jean Miriam Seeley and Gilbert Newberry Ketcham were born in Pontiac, Michigan in 1920. They both graduated from Pontiac High School in 1938 and attended Michigan State College. They married in 1941 and Ketcham joined the army in 1942 following his graduation. Seeley also graduated from Michigan State College with a degree in journalism and home economics. After graduating, she took a job as a foods editor with the Chicago Tribune and wrote under the name "Mary Starr."

Ketcham served as a member of the 433rd Antiaircraft Artillery Automatic Battalion, and was among the troops that invaded North Africa at the end of 1942. He was also present for Patton's apology after he struck a shell-shocked solider and served as a member in the Guard of Honor for the Sultan of Morocco. Following its service in North Africa, the 433rd participated in the Italian Campaign and the drive on Rome.

Ketcham returned to the United States in April of 1944 and Seeley quit her job at the Chicago Tribune. After asking an officer at the Pentagon to be assigned stateside duty, Ketcham was stationed at Camp McQuade near Capitola, California. His unit was responsible for ensuring that prisoners who went A.W.O.L. sailed on a ship to the Pacific Theater.
Ketcham left the Army in December of 1945 and returned with his wife to Pontiac. They had three children. Ketcham died in 2003.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence sent by Gilbert Ketcham to his wife, Jean Seeley Ketcham, while he was deployed overseas. The collection also contains additional correspondence, newspaper clippings, photographs, and other ephemera collected by Jean Seeley Ketcham during the war.

The majority of correspondence sent by Ketcham to his wife details the course of daily life in Army camps in North Africa and Italy. He regularly reports on films, parties put on by soldiers, meals, trips into cities and towns, and his relationship with other officers.
The collection has been arranged in a single series, Correspondence, and is stored chronologically in binders.
